comments.commentBody: These comments are invaluable.  I would add, however, that they apply just as much to the social sciences.  I teach at a "regional comprehensive" university, am tenured, and teach five courses per year, with reassigned time for directing an academic program.  Research is my first love, however, and teaching (a close second) would be impossible without it.

I respectfully disagree with this post. I think this was a severe overreaction based on fear, not reason. The cost of the shutdown was estimated at $330 million by Business Week. An estimate of the cost of the militia response was over $100 million. Economic cost is one goal of terrorism, as we know.

Second, while the bravery of the people who protect us is without dispute, the posting of the photos of those two men and the fact that a homeowner noticed a suspicious blood smear and tear on his boat cover is testament to the power of communication and the vigilance of everyday citizens. Actions such as closing selected airspace over Boston is, from my distance, an emotional, not a measured, response.

Finally, the signal that this operation sends to other actual or would-be terrorists (domestic or foreign) is that with simple pressure cookers, nails, hydrogen peroxide, etc., their violence will be amplified many times over -- sufficient to shut down a major city for a day and command unending media coverage. This is an ominous precedent, in my opinion, despite the best of intentions.

I am sorry for and feel solidarity with the people of Boston. But, next time, it could be my city or someone else's. The way we respond to these situations has implications for the future. More and more as I watch our society respond to these fits of madness, the phrase "employing an overabundance of caution" makes me more, not less, concerned.

Condolences to the victims.

Terrorists win. They now know that they don't need a 9-11 style attack. Two men with a handful of cheaply made bombs is enough to shut down a city.

Now imagine several such strikes at once in several cities across the US.

It will happen eventually because you Americans are just as naive as the Europeans and refuse to see the cold hard facts about our enemy.

Give me a break! 9000 police and national guard,100s of millions of state and federal dollars expended,shutting down an entire region of Mass.,and countless TV hours,all over a 19 year old boy? What happened to "You messed with the wrong city." In fact,he did and sucessfully.

At first glance, shutting down the city of Boston and surrounding neighborhoods might seem excessive. But given that the bombing suspects had killed an MIT police man, done a carjacking and when pursued used explosive devices and engaged in a fire fight, the police made the right call for public safety, especially since there might have been other bombs and/or accomplices was high.

The police and other first responders were in harms way in order to protect civilians. They deserve our gratitude.

Now it's time for the investigation to see if the marathon bombing could have been prevented.
As Mr. Bruni states--t's not just Texas; it's all over.

Why am I not surprised that Texas, a place where would-be policy makers propose to eliminate critical thinking from public school curricula, is the same place we now see proposals to re-orient state-supported higher education only to train people to fill narrow slots that require no broad-based knowledge or really critical intelligence?

As a tenured professor at a regional university, I am aware of state budget challenges.  Yet the phrase "state-subsidized education" leaves me cold.  It seems to imply that there is a limit to how much a society should support human thought of any sort (but especially of  the socially or politically critical sort).  Isn't thought our most valuable public good?
No.  Scientific economics is a corner of the field, practiced by expert thinkers.  It will not take over until we give up on reading entrails.

Amen! Between the fear of lobbists and the NRA plus the fear of being tea bagged in the primaries, there is no way short of martial law to influence the right wing troglodytes in Congress. Sen. Coburn believes that global warming and separation of fairy tales from state are twin hoaxes.

LBJ, then the VP, succeeded JFK.. He was not elected as successor to JFK. He was the Vice President.

JFK got NASA off the ground and aimed toward space and the moon; the challenge he had offered to the nation at his inauguration. He actually did believe, and the people believed, that they could and would make our country a better place, no matter whether they were Democrat or Republican. Getting a well-rounded college education was the best decision I made when I was younger, and I have never regretted it.  I didn't like all of my classes -- nobody does -- but even the bad ones taught me something about how to deal with the world.  I learned a foreign language, I learned about history, I learned about religion, I learned how to write a convincing argument, and I learned how to identify the stars in the sky and plants and animals living in my environment.  It is both sad and self-destructive for us to take this away from today's young people.  The problems of both today and tomorrow will require a well-rounded education and flexible minds -- not narrow job training and centrally managed curriculum.  We might save a few tax dollars on higher education in the short run with plans like these, but it will certainly cost us far more in the long run.

I say this carefully: this sort of genteel racism, denying the heavy presence of resisting forces while paternally suggesting Obama isn't qualified was common in Reconstruction salons and Romney's campaign. For all his "not knowing," how to govern is clearly not one that comports with evidence of acts, speech, facts, achievements, or conditions; in fact, governing is Obama's strong suit!

The angst here should not be over Obama's achievements--though I think too many columnists are using old paradigms in a new era--but that the column contributes to the further erosion of journalism standards! Column writers were once expected to be aware of other voices. To use inductive logic to tie specific cases and conclusions to the larger context. This column is an echo chamber of word play; cute tricks and sentence licks. It provides, by proxy and example, cover for the more egregious examples of public discourse that qualify as the looking glass syndrome: those who simply proclaim it is what I say! What I call the myth of because.

It is possible to build a case using the process entrusted to journalism, but today, ends are valued above means. That inversion of values muddles facts, ignores positions, and reduces a dialogue to sound bites and robs us of real discovery and engagement.

It's not the writing or the star power that special, it's the process. I wish that we could protect it and agree on its importance and use.

To add to the wide and ever expanding ways and examples of how to blame the victim for the faults of the system or others, especially within the historic legacy of race in America, a review, representative offenses listed first:

"Running away." A very bad thing; those enslaved who did, were scientifically diagnosed with drapetomania, a mental disorder identified by a GA physician. Whipping was the cure.

"Uppity." Failing to display proper deference to whites after freedom. Beatings/Murder/lynching were punishments. (Riots in Oklahoma City, Cincinnati, et.al.)

"Laughing." Stick your head in the discreetly placed laughing barrels to preserve the peace. (Sundown towns."Be out by dark;" IN, IL, AK, MO, map used online today by supremacists who laugh that it was prepared by a black scholar.)

"Becoming an officer." Shunned, given the silent treatment for all 4 years at West Point (Henry Flipper).

"Organizing for civil rights." Malcontent communists; lose of passports, arrests, intimidation, phone taps, spying, and secret files used to track/restrict Robeson, DuBois, King, Malcolm, et. al.

"Perfecting the union." Reverse discrimination.

New: "Getting elected to high office." Brady, favored, fell short, but Harold Washington knew as does Barack Obama what (and why!) it is impossible to "learn" (condescending!) how to govern--as did Mr. Mandela, Gandhi, Nkrumah, Allende, and others denied for great periods the opportunity to "learn."

I really think VSP stands for Very Selfish People. The fact that most legislators on both sides of the aisle are multi-millionaires concerns me. For whether you believe in heaven or not it is certainly easier for a camel to fit through the eye of a needle then for a rich man to feel empathy for the masses.

It's all well and good that the IMF study discredited A-A, but with whom? Certainly not the powers that be in Europe, the UK, or here. Is there anything that can discredit the view that austerity economics are bad? I think the answer is no and for the same reason that good guys with guns is better than less guns all the way around.

It's not about the logic of things. Even the math is inconsequential to these people. Look at Ryan's budgets!

In the end, what will win out is the politics side of the equation. Get more of the people on board with the idea that the leadership they elected is working against them, the more hope there is that they'll wake up and unleash their wrath by the mid-term elections.

If the Dems win big, one of the first things they had better do is fix education from pre-K through grad school. We are in this mess, in no small part, due to the fact that all this econ talk is gobbledygook to a lot of people.
I wonder if you will inspire John's avatar?

VSPs are not in the business of doing economic research or vetting the research done by others. They are in the business of ferreting out stories that appeal to their publishers and the advertisers who pay for the clicks on their web sites. Then they ferret out the apparently credible sources that seem to support their preconceptions. Peer review is the occasional salvo from a moderate.

Neocons, Free Market Fundamentalists, VSPs, and Republican politicians could care less about being proven wrong. They frequently tell transparent lies just to prove that all politicians and commentators are always lying. Their strategy is to destroy the credibility of everyone who has anything to say about policy and the way the economy works. Then they hope to be free to use their quasi-religious economic philosophy to run the economies of Europe and the US.

Economists have built models, estimated relationships, and pored over test statistics since Lawrence Klein, Otto Eckstein, Dan Suits, and Arthur Goldberger were young. Econometrics has advanced prodigiously. Christopher Simms, Robert Hall, Jerry Hausman, and many others are all alive and well. Anyone interested is vetting A-A and R-R could have obtained a sympathetic impartial opinion from them. The authors could have obtained opinions from such people prior to circulating the papers. Why don’t we take a poll this week? Everyone who reads this blog could call some qualified econometrician and ask for a quick review.

My husband who graduated with a BA in English is an electrician who heard at least 4 times other individuals in his work area make references to the Marathon bombers to his Ukrainian coworker  (things like "where were you, hiding in a boat?").  Needless to say, most of his coworkers are graduates of technical training (apprenticeships).  He admonished the group at lunch by telling them first, Christian Ukrainians are not connected to Islamic Chechnians.  And even if the guy was from Chechnya, they cannot keep excluding people and treating them like the other-(as there was some mean spirited gossip about a gay apprentice who dropped out of the program)-- because there is always someone else that is different and one day it might be the overweight or the over-40 (as he pointedly looked at an obese worker and an older worker).  Liberal education gives one tools for critical thinking and the ability to combat ignorance.  Little wonder Rick Perry doesn't value it.

This is one of the cases where everyone is a little bit right. I think we do need to question the role of big universities as a place for undergraduate education. The biggest major in this country is 'business' so the romantics for liberal arts should put their thoughts aside. Also many of the entry-level jobs--think 'junior benefits analyst' or 'assistant account executive'-- that went to liberal arts grads have been replaced by web technology. We have an expensive 'right of passage' in this country.

I attended a mid-size private research university and found little impact of the research that professors did on my classes. Undergrads have little contact with faculty as they go from lectures that decrease from 1000 to 200 and may encounter a tenured professor once by the time they graduate. TAs teach recitations and small classes. Many students get emotionally lost in the party culture. I don't think many students take advantage of the events and academic climate of a big school. Still I think it is worthwhile to have college graduates who know the difference between Chechnya and the Czech Republic.

Bob, you might want to take a look at the courses that are now being offered under the category of "literature", etc. They are the subject of the recent spat between the head of Bowdoin College, Mills, and a private philanthropist/investor, Klingenstein.

Criticism of higher education is entirely appropriate. It, too, can lose its way and need refocusing.

Frankly I don't know what to do with the long life available to most these days without something new to learn every day.

But I think one is ready to graduate from schooling and go to work when one demonstrates the capacity and interest to self-educate unless one plans to become an educator oneself.

Bob,

I am glad your hires worked out for you. I can guarantee you that the ones you rejected probably did as well or better than the ones you hired. How do I know? It is because I would hire those in your reject pile.

I like the humanities. I greatly enjoy reading the classics even today.

What I detested during college was taking courses in the humanities. The classes would be grindingly slow to build up the discussion to points that were rather obvious to many of us.

I would suggest that if it takes four years for someone to learn "how to think", that they perhaps are not college ready in the first place.

As a hiring manager at a major electronics firm I had the opportunity to review the resumes and transcripts of recent engineering graduates. I found a number of applicants top-heavy in STEM subjects but without a single course in literature, history, or language. No philosophy or psychology, no comparative religion, no social anthropology or sociology. No political science, music, or fine arts.

True, many of these applicants had been trained in the latest tool or technique and likely could step right in to solve problems they were given. But I passed on every one of them because I wanted people on my team who had gotten an *education*, and with it the prospect of lifelong learning, not just *training* that would be obsolete in a year or two. I was never disappointed.

A strong comment. However, saying that "if you want to take gender studies, that's fine, go to private school," -- is more or less comparable to Marie Antoinette's "let them eat cake." is a bit much. A starving peasant scraping charred "cake" from the sides of bread ovens is not comparable to a student's unmet desire to study gender issues on the public's dime.

Frank, thank you. Thank God someone at the Times is finally putting this discussion before the nation. We are seeing public investment in higher education -- pioneered by Thomas Jefferson -- gutted. Our state universities have been and are still places where someone's life can be transformed. I've seen it happen. If current trends continue, this won't be true much longer. Your point about anti-intellectualism couldn't be more correct, and it's amazing how such prejudices are used to turn people against themselves. The ideal was that in America you should be able to get an education if you were willing to work for it, whatever your background or means. There was a notion that we shouldn't instate the two-tiered system of many countries, in which most people -- from lower and lower-middle class backgrounds -- would be siphoned into technical school while the elites got an elite education and ran the country, business, etc, as they always had. The American vision for publicly supported education had so much more, well, vision. The governor of North Carolina's comment --  "if you want to take gender studies, that's fine, go to private school," --  is more or less comparable to Marie Antoinette's "let them eat cake." It reflects a naive -- or willful? -- ignorance of everything from the value of knowledge in the humanities to the financial exigencies of most people. Elites, if they are smart, can go to the Ivy League -- or to China. For the rest, there's always vocational school.

Beautifully expressed.

I would add that sometimes parents are at fault, as they pressure their children to choose majors and courses solely because it will net them jobs.

Recently, my niece - a junior at an excellent state university - told me she was 'totally stressed out' and contemplating her triple (!) major in two areas she wasn't that keen on because she thought it would get her hired. Plus, she was not majoring in something that really turned her on.

This from a smart, dynamic, big-thinking young woman who cares about world problems, has already won leadership awards for her extra-curricular activities, and will no doubt be successful at whatever she does.

Isn't what you do with your time worth something? Strikes me as tragic.
Einstein lost his welcome in physics before he died. Something about refusing to accept the logic of what has become the dead end standard model of physics.
Sean:  A+

Steve Jobs took courses at community colleges in things like origami and calligraphy only to revolutionize the world.

Steve Wynn, the Las Vegas hotel mogul, reinvented the city with an English degree.

Einstein was an avid violinist who used his music as inspiration for his science. He also read extensively and would likely marvel at the myopia now gripping American conservatives when it comes to education.

A college education is meant not only to educate, but to inspire. Great professors strive to inspire students while guiding them to seek out new ways of thinking and experiencing the world. A university education isn't vocational training, and it wasn't meant to be. The university is an incubator of thought, intellectual growth and inquiry, and a journey unto itself.

If someone went to college and learned nothing, it's not the college's fault; it's theirs.

We can get some rough estimates about this. The total financial wealth of the U.S. is around $142 trillion.

http://rutledgecapital.com/2009/05/24/total-assets-of-the-us-economy-188...

The top 1% own at least 37.1% of this, of $52 trillion.

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wealth_in_the_United_States

A 2% wealth tax would be a trillion dollars a year, which would balance the budget (current deficit under $800 billion) immediately.

How long it would take to pay off the debt is a little trickier to calculate, but it estimating it in 20 years seems a bit conservative, really.

Why is it such a rare occurrence to hear someone speak this message?

Why are we so eager to give everyone, even the most hateful, lunatics among us the benefit of the doubt? We seem to start every message with the implicit assumption that we all want the same thing.

This is simply not true. Socialized losses, privatized gains and an endless stream of self-serving legislation attacking everything from financial regulation, public schools and environmental protection are the goals of the day. Improving the lives of our country as a whole is a non-issue.

Are lawmakers ignorant, uneducated, hateful, spiteful, corrupt? Does it matter?

If security is that important to them and what's being stolen is that valuable then maybe, just maybe, they'll put some effort into protecting it.

As was pointed out earlier, Windows is horrible when it comes to security. If we actually tried to protect our intellectual property and refused to use systems that are the equivalent of Swiss-cheese firewalls, perhaps it wouldn't be that easy for folks to steal it.

Exactly, and another failure of Paul Krugman is that he does not distinguish very different situations in different countries and calls for the same remedy for all.
What in common between an european country where collective spending amounts to 60% of GDP, where taxes and deficits are all the way up and productive investment down for years and the US ?

Bob, an educated person is not someone who has taken courses in literature, history or language. A truly educated person is someone whose intellectual interests will prompt him or her to explore literature, history, and others outside college.

Most of us need courses to steer us through the study of, say, electrodynamics, with the appropriate prerequisites in math. We don't really need courses to read "Pride and Prejudice", and people who read it because they want to read it will probably enjoy it a great deal more than those who read it to get a good grade on a course.
